channel.title: programming on JJasonClark.com
channel.description: Recent content in programming on JJasonClark.com

item.title: Trying out Emacs Again
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: I'm a Vim user, but i'm not 100% sold on it. I keep wanting to find an even better editor. I've tried just about everything but nothing sticks. I'm starting a new book on Lisp programming so it is time to try Emacs again. May this time it will stick.

item.title: Sinatra Settings for Nested Apps
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: Getting settings to work in a Sinatra app that includes other Sinatra apps can be done a lot easier than you think using the Rack::Config middleware. I show how I created a Sinatra app with several nested Sinatra apps. And how I solved the issue with using a shared settings value from outer apps to the inner apps.

item.title: Vagrant Going from old and busted, to new hotness
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: Vagrant is an amazing application for helping you manage your virtual machines. Renewed development effort by it's creators has brought us many new features. Unfortunately this forced a change in the semantics of the Vagrantfile. Here is how to do the most basic upgrades to remove the warning messages Vagrant creates from using the older file type.

item.title: Switching from attr_encrypted gem to attr_encryptor for better security
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: At work we are using the attr_encrypted gem to encrypt some PII on our data before it hits the database. The gem supports using a strong key but this turns out to not be enough. A Github issue was created to address leaking of data caused by using the same initialization vector (IV) and salt for every value. The method used by the attr_encrypted gem to create the IV and salt values is vulnerable. Additionally the IV should also be processed with the CBC-MAC method. The attr_encryptor was created to fix these issues.

item.title: Setting up a new Mac for Ruby development
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: I recently switched how I was using one of my laptops. I wanted to make a clean break from what it was doing before, so I erased the hard drive and started from scratch. I've done this a few times already and I always seem to forget a step. So this time I wrote down the steps so I could repeat them later. These are the steps I take to setup a Mac for Ruby development using Vim as the editor and MySql as the database. Of course there are a few other programs that I use while developing. The whole group, in my opinion, make for the most basic setup.

item.title: Fizz-buzz rehash
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: An implementation of fizz-buzz that is overly complex. Something you want to avoid in an interview.

item.title: Any() is your friend
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: The Any() extension method helps make much more efficient SQL queries. Use it and love it!

item.title: How to fix patching problems with TortoiseSVN and TortoiseMerge
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: TortoiseMerge occasionally fails to work. I don't know the cause, but I did figure out how correct the issue so you can do another merge.

item.title: Alt.Net Seattle mini con report
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: I went to my first Alt.Net Seattle meeting on Saturday. It was a mini conference created so the Microsoft MVPs could meet while they were already in Seattle for the MVP global summit. I have to say I really liked it.

item.title: Started working with Silverlight
item.author: jason@jjasonclark.com (Jason Clark)
item.description: I started playing with Silverlight 2.0. I learned a lot about the data modeling classes and what is supported. Going to have to spend much more time with Silverlight if I'm going to make anything useful
